titleStmt.title: Lega Toscana di Protezione Meeting Minutes: Volume 1

respStmt.resp: Meeting minutes transcribed from scanned immages
TEI file created from transcribed minute log for academic use

respStmt.orgName: Center for the Digital Text at the University of Pittsburgh, Greensburg

availability.p: The materials transcribed below are available for public use in the Detre Library & Archives located in the Heinz History Center. Materials cannot be removed from the library and archives, but sharing of the documents digitally for educational purposes is encouraged, with full and proper citation.

msIdentifier.repository: Detre Library & Archives, Italian American Collection

handDesc.p: This volume of minutes was written by an **indistinct number of contributors**

accMat.p: The meeting minutes contain, in addition to written record of meetings, expense sheets that describe account balances and any spending or receipt of money by the organization.

origin.p: The manuscript was compiled by Lega members during the monthly meetings that took place in Pittsburgh, PA. This volume contains meeting minutes that span from January of 1919 to December of 1925, and were written by the designated secratary at the point of the meeting - a position that changed hands a number of times throughout the compilation of meeting notes.

acquisition.p: The manuscript documents were donated to theHeinz History CenterbyLaura Bocelli-Vondasin two portions - the first in 2015 and the second in 2017.

textDesc.factuality: The meeting minutes were handwritten accounts of discussions held, decisions, or money allocated made during the meetings.

abstract.p: This research study is a collaborative effort between four undergraduate students and one faculty member at the University of Pittsburgh in Pittsburgh, PA to explore geographical, linguistic, and anthropological information regarding members and affiliates of the Lega Toscana di Protezione, a Pittsburgh-based fraternal group of Tuscan Italian immigrants. The primary purpose of this specific file is to contain specially marked-up renditionsof the transcribed minutes in order to create a social network mapping that will illuminate relationships and dynamics between both members of the Lega and those in the greater community based on varied types of interactions represented within the minutes log.
